history.content:
You're probably not going to fail dude, the average grade in the class is an A-

If anything, you might get a B- at worst.

----------

Talk to the prof about your concerns first. 

----------

Not a huge fan of the first response and of mitigating other people's academic struggles... callin' you out, original responder. 

+1; For me I had a lot of trouble in the class and I bombed the final (1.5 SD below) but because I talked with the prof I was able to pass.

-----------

If you're having difficulties in the class, please reach out to the staff and professors.  We're here to help.   -Harrison

I appreciate the student advice to speak with your instructors and/or 16A TAs. To answer your question about repeating, in EECS, if you get below a C- you may repeat the course and have the 2nd grade be included in your GPA. The first grade will remain on your transcript, however. This rule is only applicable to the first 12 units of repeated classes.

See: "Repetition of Courses" http://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide/procedures-and-regulations

There's a good chance I'm going to get lower than a C in EE16A this sem. As an EECS major, am I in big trouble or can I retake the class in a future semester and replace the grade on my transcript? I searched for this question on here and got some idea of an answer, but from posts tagged LSCS, not EECS.
history.subject: Failing EE16A as EECS major
